entry.title: Organizational Structure - SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud
entry.content:
Organizational Structure - SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud

In order to understand the organogram of any organization, it is essential to learn the functions of every org unit. Just like in a family, some people play the roles of guardians, supervisors and some are only dependents on elder, likewise SAP org units are. 
Every organization utilizes its resources to earn profits so from where can we extract the profitability reports? It means there is a unit made responsible to collect information, analyse and report it in every manner that is "CO-PA". (Controlling- Profitability Segment). So, Operating Concern is like a super power who sits on the top of the org structure and have all the information. In SAP Public Cloud one operating concern is predefined with name of A000 therefore CO Consultant do not need to create any other.   It is assigned to controlling area, where all variable and fixed costs of the company is stored. Just like there cannot remain two swords in one sheath, similarly two controlling areas cannot be created. In SAP Public Cloud one controlling area is predefined with name of A000 therefore CO Consultant do not need to create any other. 

The world of Finance begin when companies start trading, hence just like we have multiple universes, multiple company codes are assigned to controlling areas. Company code is the smallest org structure in FI that stores all financial documents line items. It becomes a base for MM and SD structure, an independent family member upon which other gets dependent. Company codes nomenclature can be alpha-numeric. FI Consultant will begin the org structure creation activity in SAP Public Cloud. Lets take one scenario as an example. lets say a group of companies will be made as a company and its subsidiaries will be configured as separate company codes. 

Plant is the area which is responsible to record every production activity. What is happening inside a plant, cannot be known to that person who is sitting on the head of the family chair on the dining table. (CO-PA). Therefore, MM Consultant configures the alphanumeric plants to the company codes and with this relation, correct information passes to controlling area and reports of profit gets extracted. Profit is made of Revenue-Costs, so costs are available with controlling area, but what about revenue? 

So we have another stream, another module i,e SD who is solely responsible to dispatch and record sales. Then like a river, it flows into the sea of Finance and gets connected to CO-PA. 

MM and SD are two extreme opposite sides, SD is a plus and MM is minus. (Inflows and outflows) MM has its own purchasing org, that can either be centralized or decentralized as per company's policies. 
Similarly, SD has its own sales org,  SD consultant can assign one on multiple company codes or create a decentralized structure. 

In connection to controlling area. CO consultant designs a hierarchy of cost centers and profit centers to record their activities. Purchases can be found in multiple cost centers, and via report it can be plan to control it. Whereas, sales can be assigned profitability segments to know their contributions in profit figures. 

Under plant, multiple storage locations for inventory can be configured and assigned and under the same plant, sales area is made. Sales area is the combination of sales org, divisions and distribution channel. The longest activity in org structure is of SD module.  

The material is either procured externally or produced in-house, it moves from plant to warehouse, then stamped in sales office, it dispatches from shipping points to final consumer and consumer happily transfers the receipt in company's bank account. That's how production is materialized into finance. 

Please note no consultant can begin configuration without completing the organisational structure. 

It can be edited and recreated later on. but it will lock your workspace for sometime. After doing changes, confirm the units and deploy it onto your configuration server. 

Reports are formulated with the help of transactions, if a purchase order is made in MM, check the org units, (plant, purchasing org and storage location)  will be filled, so automatically it will be assigned to its respective company code and would reach CO-PA. SD will also follow the same in its preliminary financial documents. Hence, create a strong structure to uphold the data in correct formats and form. 

Till now, we have CO-FI-MM and SD in the picture and that's how organisational structure is framed in SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud. The role of CO is predefined, in Grey cannot be changed in any circumstances.

entry.title: Switching Your Tax Procedure or External Tax Provider (United States Sales and Use Tax)
entry.content:
To state the obvious: Getting your taxes right is an important part of your business, and it‚Äôs not an area where you‚Äôd typically seek out additional complexities.

This is the shortest possible version of why it‚Äôs difficult to change your sales and use tax procedure in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Your tax procedure is something you set up in your initial scoping, and it is in most cases the deepest asleep of all of your sleeping dogs. Almost all the time, you just want to leave it alone.

Almost. There are times when you need to make a change. Perhaps your business structure has changed sufficiently that you want to move from the internal tax calculation procedure to the external and join up with a tax partner. Or maybe you need to switch tax partners.

In these cases, with live systems, you need to think carefully, plan for disruption, think again, and plan some more. And then probably do that one more time. Then if you‚Äôre going ahead, consult our KBA entitled Information on the Internal Tax Calculation Procedure (TAXUSJ) to the External Tax Calculation Procedure (0TXUSX) for more detailed information on the procedure, risks, and potential downtimes associated with such a switch.

entry.title: Accounting Principles and SAP S/4HANA FI
entry.content:
It‚Äôs common to hear colleagues from other S4Hana modules express frustration with the complexity and impact of FI/CO on their processes. However, this perception often stems from a fundamental misunderstanding: the organizational structure of SAP S/4HANA Finance is not merely technical; it is the practical embodiment of the accounting principles that govern the financial governance of any organization.

Every object, from Company Code to Segment, is meticulously designed to ensure that financial records adhere to the pillars of accounting‚Äîpromoting integrity, transparency, and, crucially, supporting strategic decision-making.

This article explores the intrinsic relationship between accounting principles and organizational objects in SAP S/4HANA FI, demystifying why their influence is so broad and vital to a company‚Äôs financial health. Get ready for an analysis that goes beyond technical configuration, diving into the accounting logic behind each system structure.

I‚Äôve broken the concepts into levels to make them easier to understand.

 

Level 1: The Legal Entity and Going Concern in SAP S/4HANA

The starting point of any robust accounting system lies in properly defining the entity and in the premise of its uninterrupted operation. In SAP S/4HANA, these concepts are solidly embedded in its foundational organizational objects.

Entity Principle: The Company Code as the Legal Unit

The Entity Principle is one of the pillars of accounting, establishing that a company‚Äôs assets are distinct from those of its owners or shareholders. Accounting is therefore maintained for the business entity as an economically and legally separate unit.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Company Code is the most direct and crucial representation of this principle.

The Company Code is the smallest organizational unit for which a complete and self-contained set of accounts can be created, enabling the generation of external financial statements such as Balance Sheets and Income Statements, as required by law. Configuring a Company Code in SAP is, in fact, defining the legal and asset boundaries that the Entity Principle demands.

All financial transactions‚Äîwhether purchases, sales, or payments‚Äîare recorded within a specific Company Code, ensuring segregation and clarity of each legal entity‚Äôs finances.

Going Concern Principle: The Long-Term Assumption in FI-AA

The Going Concern Principle assumes that the entity will continue operating indefinitely, with no intent of liquidation or significant downsizing. This is fundamental for classifying assets and liabilities (current vs. non-current) and, notably, for depreciating assets over their useful lives.

In SAP S/4HANA, the long-term existence of the Company Code, together with specific modules like Fixed Assets (FI-AA), reflects this principle directly.

FI-AA, configured per Company Code, manages asset depreciation across multiple years‚Äîa process that only makes sense under the assumption of continued operations. The system is inherently designed to handle the full lifecycle of assets and liabilities, which is a direct and systemic application of the Going Concern Principle.

 

Level 2: Measurement and Recording of Activities ‚Äì The Basis of Accounting in S/4HANA

Once the entity is established, the next step is ensuring all financial activities are measured and recorded consistently and accurately. SAP S/4HANA provides robust tools aligned with essential accounting principles.

Monetary Unit Principle: Currency and Chart of Accounts

The Monetary Unit Principle requires all transactions and economic events to be expressed in a single currency. This enables aggregation, comparison, and consistent analysis of financial data.

In SAP S/4HANA, this principle is realized through the Company Code Currency and the Chart of Accounts.

Each Company Code is configured with a local currency (e.g., BRL, USD), in which all legal reports are generated. Regardless of the original transaction currency, amounts are converted and recorded in this common denominator. The Chart of Accounts, assigned to the Company Code, provides the structured hierarchy for recording economic events in an organized and standardized manner, allocating monetary values to categories such as Assets, Liabilities, Revenue, and Expenses.

Accrual and Matching Principles: The Universal Journal as the Core of Recording

The Accrual and Matching Principles are critical for accurate income determination.

  • Accrual Principle: Revenues and expenses must be recognized in the period in which they are generated, regardless of cash flow.

  • Matching Principle: Revenues must be matched with the expenses that contributed to generating them, preventing distortions in the Income Statement.

SAP S/4HANA fundamentally operates on an accrual basis. Fiscal Year Variants structure periods (usually monthly) and control postings, ensuring that an August sales invoice is recorded in August, even if payment occurs in September.

The Universal Journal (ACDOCA table) is the ‚Äúsingle source of truth.‚Äù Every posting of revenue or expense is registered with both posting and document dates, ensuring proper period recognition. By unifying FI and CO data, the Universal Journal enables direct matching of revenues with their related costs‚Äîall in one place.

Native integration across SD (Sales & Distribution), MM (Materials Management), and FI automates matching. For instance, a goods issue in SD automatically triggers inventory reduction in MM and simultaneously records both Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) and revenue in FI. Likewise, FI-AA automatically posts depreciation monthly, while Cost Centers in CO record operating expenses that can be matched against generated results.

 

Level 3: Managerial Analysis and Reporting ‚Äì Beyond Statutory Accounting

Beyond legal requirements, managers need granular insight into business performance. SAP S/4HANA applies accounting principles at an internal level to provide valuable managerial insights.

Segment Reporting (IFRS 8): The Segment Object

IFRS 8 (CPC 22 in Brazil) requires publicly traded companies to disclose information about their operating segments, enabling investors to analyze the business as management does.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Segment object is specifically designed for this. Derived at posting (often from Profit Centers), it enables real-time balance sheets and income statements per segment via the Universal Journal, providing unprecedented transparency into performance across business lines or geographies.

Internal Matching Principle: Profit Center and Cost Center

For managerial performance evaluation, revenues must be matched with the costs incurred to generate them.

  • Profit Center: Represents a unit accountable for its own P&L, capturing revenues and expenses. It applies the matching principle internally, enabling profitability analysis of products, branches, or divisions.

  • Cost Center: Represents where costs are incurred (e.g., HR, IT), without directly generating revenue. Costs are controlled here and can later be allocated to Profit Centers for full profitability analysis.

Together, Profit and Cost Centers close the cycle of internal matching.

 Prudence (Conservatism) Principle: Credit Control Area

The Prudence Principle dictates that, when in doubt, record the least favorable outcome‚Äîlower assets/revenues and higher liabilities/expenses. In practice, this means caution and recognition of probable losses.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Credit Control Area embodies this principle. By setting credit limits and monitoring exposures, it helps manage default risk. Functionality like provisions for doubtful accounts (bad debt allowances) within FI applies prudence directly, recognizing probable expenses before losses materialize.

 

Level 4: Information Quality and Systemic Governance in S/4HANA

Building an accounting structure is just step one. The next, equally critical, is ensuring that the information flowing through it is reliable, consistent, and accurate. SAP S/4HANA achieves this via its integrated architecture and intrinsic controls‚Äîsystemic embodiments of governance and data quality principles.

Consistency Principle: Operational Chart of Accounts and Posting Models

The Consistency Principle requires that companies apply the same accounting practices across periods, allowing comparability over time. Changes are allowed only if preferable and properly disclosed.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Operational Chart of Accounts‚Äîonce defined‚Äîbecomes the backbone of all postings. Using a single chart across a group ensures uniform treatment of similar transactions across entities. Posting Models and Screen Variants enforce standardized postings for recurring transactions, reinforcing consistency and reducing manual errors.

Integrity, Completeness, and Synchronization of Data: Universal Journal and Native Integration

Data governance principles‚ÄîIntegrity, Completeness, Synchronization‚Äîare fundamental to information reliability.

  • Integrity ensures accuracy and trustworthiness.

  • Completeness ensures all required data is captured.

  • Synchronization ensures consistency across accounting, managerial, and logistics views.

The Universal Journal achieves this by merging FI, CO, FI-AA, CO-PA, and ML into a single line-item repository. This eliminates complex reconciliations.

Native integration ensures that when goods movement is posted in MM, the corresponding FI entry is simultaneously generated. No batch transfers that can fail; if one part fails, the transaction is reversed entirely, ensuring integrity.

The Universal Journal structure, containing all relevant fields (company, account, cost center, profit center, segment, etc.) in one table, ensures completeness. Its ‚Äúsingle source of truth‚Äù architecture means all views‚Äîstatutory and managerial‚Äîare instantly updated, eliminating reconciliations that plagued earlier SAP versions.

 

Conclusion: SAP S/4HANA as an Enabler of Accounting Governance

Understanding the deep connection between accounting principles and SAP S/4HANA FI architecture is crucial for every consultant. Far from being just a transactional system, S/4HANA is a platform that incorporates and automates accounting principles, ensuring not only legal compliance but also real-time financial insights for strategic decision-making.

By mastering this synergy, consultants can go beyond technical configuration and act as true business partners‚Äîoptimizing processes, safeguarding data integrity, and maximizing the value SAP S/4HANA delivers to financial governance.

The evolution of ERP into S/4HANA represents a qualitative leap in how companies manage their finances‚Äîtransforming accounting principles into operational and strategic reality.

entry.title: Plant Maintenance Integration with FICO,MM,PP, QM,HCM,EHS and other modules
entry.content:
Plant maintenance integrates with many of the modules and below are the some of the modules that plant maintenance integrates with: 

FICO(Finance and controlling) :- 

Below are the integration points of plant maintenance with FICO.
Company Code: - A plant will always be assigned to the company code. 
Cost center: - Cost Center is an organizational unit within a controlling area that is used to collect and record costs incurred from business activities.
Investment order: -  investment order needs cost budgeting for an order will be done.
Allocation Structure: -  In the allocation structure the cost elements will be taken from the CO in which these cost elements will gets reflected is any maintenance order have consumption of materials, Labour cost, 3rd party material procurement etc... which will flow the costs to the FI. 
Asset master creation: - When an equipment is being created then the asset will be created with a configuration.
Settlement Of an Order: - The settlement of an order is actually being done for an order because at the cost needs to be settled.
Settlement Profile: - The settlement profile will be assigned to the order type.
Activity Type: - In activity type the price or the cost for labour per hour will be determined by FICO consultant and we need to maintain the activity type in the work center.

PP(Production Planning) :- 
Work Center: - In work center the capacity will be determined by the production planning team. Here the capacity refers to the availability of people and resources for maintenance work.
Equipment Master Data: - In equipment master data there is a field work center in the Location in which we need to give the production planning work center and whereas in the organization. 
Spare Part Preparation: - For example the spare part cannot be procured externally then the spare part will be produced by the production order and the settlement rule of order will be done to the maintenance order.
Refurbishment of Material:- Refurbishment of material will be done if any material in production needs to be repaired as soon as possible then we will just refurbish the material and replace the material within the machine as it was there before the breakdown.

MM(Material Management):-
Components:- The components that are required for maintenance of machine will be taken from the inventory.
Service Entry Sheet:- To procure the service from external that is the maintenance has to be done for a machine and there is no team that is present in the plant(internal team) then we will just raise purchase requestion from the maintenance order and after it the material management people will procure the service through ML81N."
Split valuation:- Split valuation for a material has to be configured so that we can perform the refurbishment order.
Details of plant:- The details of plant related namely Purchase Organization, Vendor, Supplier, Outline agreement number etc..
Serial Number Profile:- A serial number profile must be configured for the material to enable the creation of equipment for that material.
Goods Issue:- Goods issue needs to be done for the order otherwise the technician cannot perform the maintenance activities that are present in the order.
Goods Receipt:- Goods receipt has to be done for the Internal Refurbishment Order and the settlement will be done for the material.
Material Reservation:- after creating the maintenance order the materials will be reserved in the inventory automatically.
Procurement:- Procuring of non-stock material, service entry sheet through purchase requestion.

Quality Management:- 
CatLog Profile:- Catlog profile will be configured by the quality management team and it will be assigned for the equipment , functional location.
Calibration Order:- In calibration order inspection will be done and thereby the equipment can be used or not will be determined by the quality management team.

SD(Sales And Distribution):- 
The place where the sales and distribution as well as plant maintenance will gets integrated is in customer service module.

EHS(Environment Health & Safety):-
The integration part of PM with EHS comes only at the product safety, Work permit - while performing any maintenance at the dangerous or hazardous material or equipment's.

FREM(Flexible Real Estate Management):- 
Flexible real estate management and plant maintenance both comes under Enterprise Asset Management in SAP S/4 Hana.
Real Estate Object: - Real estate object will be considered as functional location/equipment.
Work order:- Notification and work order management √† maintenance requests originating from RE-FX can be turned into PM notifications/ orders but this will be done with the help of CRM.
Service Provider Coordination: - PM order can trigger external services with the help of MM (material management) to work on RE-FX managed asset.

HCM(Human Capital Management):-
Person Responsible:- Here the person can be assigned to the work order , work center, Technical Object, Operations in work order too.

DMS(Document Management System):-
Documents can be uploaded for the technical objects, notifications , work orders etc... for information or to follow the rules to keep the equipment runs smoothly.

The above are some of the modules for which the plant maintenance will integrate with.

Hope its informative and feel free to comment for any improvements or suggestions.

Regards,
Neeraj.

entry.title: Mass Download Of Attachment In SAP Document / Invoice - SAP S4HANA / FICO
entry.content:
SAP offers various functionalities to manage attachments, but the mass download of invoice attachments is not a standard, out-of-the-box feature. This is a common pain point for many SAP users, especially in Accounts Payable departments, who need to archive or audit a large volume of invoices with their corresponding attachments.

In this blog post, we will explore the different ways to achieve this, from standard transactions to custom solutions, providing a comprehensive guide for anyone looking to streamline this process.

 

The Challenge of Mass Attachment Download in SAP

Standard SAP transactions like FB03 (Display Document) or MIR4 (Display Invoice Document) allow you to view attachments individually. However, they lack a function to download a large number of attachments at once. This becomes a significant bottleneck when:

  • Auditing: You need to provide a complete set of invoices and attachments to internal or external auditors.

  • Archiving: You are migrating documents to an external content management system or preparing for a system shutdown.

  • Reporting: You need to extract a bulk of data with attachments for analytical purposes.

So, how can you tackle this challenge? Let's delve into the methods available.

 

Method 1: The Manual, Item-by-Item Approach (Not Recommended for Mass)

 

This method is only feasible for a very small number of invoices and serves as a good starting point to understand where attachments are stored.

  1. Navigate to the Invoice: Use transaction FB03 (for FI documents) or MIR4 (for Logistics Invoice Verification).

  2. Access the Services for Object icon: This is the small icon with a paperclip and a piece of paper, typically found in the top-left corner of the screen.

  3. View and Download: From the dropdown menu, select Attachment list. A window will pop up showing all the attachments linked to that document. You can then select and download each one individually.

Why this isn't a long-term solution: This process is extremely time-consuming and prone to human error. It's simply not practical for mass downloads.

 

Method 2: The Semi-Automated SO_OBJECT_DOWNLOAD Function Module

 

For those with some technical know-how, this method provides a way to download attachments programmatically, but still on a document-by-document basis.

  1. Identify the Document Key: Each attachment is linked to an object key in SAP. You can find this by navigating to SOBJ table or through the attachment list pop-up screen.

  2. Execute SO_OBJECT_DOWNLOAD: Go to transaction SE37 and execute the function module SO_OBJECT_DOWNLOAD.

  3. Provide the Object Key: In the function module parameters, input the object key of the attachment you want to download. You can then execute it to save the file to your local drive.

Limitations: This method is still not a true "mass" download solution. It requires you to know the object key for each attachment, which means you would need to write a custom program to get this data in the first place.

 

Method 3: The Custom ABAP Program (The Most Effective Solution)

 

This is the most common and robust solution for mass downloads. It requires the expertise of an ABAP developer but provides the flexibility to meet your specific business requirements.

How a Custom Program Works:

A well-designed ABAP program for mass downloads would typically follow these steps:

  1. Input Parameters: The program should have a selection screen where the user can input a range of invoice document numbers, vendor numbers, posting dates, or other relevant criteria.

  2. Retrieve Document List: The program will read the relevant SAP tables (e.g., BKPF for document headers, RSEG for invoice documents) to get a list of all invoices that meet the selection criteria.

  3. Link to Attachments: For each invoice document found, the program will query the attachment tables. The primary tables for object links are SRGBTBREL (Relations between Business Objects) and SOFFCONT1 (the actual content of the documents).

  4. Download and Save: The program will then loop through each attachment found, retrieve its content from SOFFCONT1, and save it to a specified folder on the user's local machine or a network drive. The filename can be dynamically generated using the invoice number, vendor number, or other relevant data for easy identification.

  5. Logging and Reporting: The program should generate a log showing which documents were processed, which attachments were downloaded successfully, and which ones failed (e.g., if there was no attachment).

*&--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report:           ZFI_INV_DOWN_ATTACH
*& Description:      Report to Download FB03 attachments
*&--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Date          Developer    Transport         Change/Description
*&----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
REPORT zfi_inv_down_attach.
TABLES : bkpf,regup.

TYPES : BEGIN OF gty_bkpf ,
          bukrs TYPE bkpf-bukrs,
          belnr TYPE bkpf-belnr,
          gjahr TYPE bkpf-gjahr,
        END OF gty_bkpf.
TYPES : BEGIN OF gty_output ,
          files TYPE string,
          bukrs TYPE bkpf-bukrs,
          gjahr TYPE bkpf-gjahr,
          belnr TYPE bkpf-belnr,
        END OF gty_output.
DATA: lt_bkpf    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gty_bkpf,
      ls_bkpf    TYPE gty_bkpf,
      lt_output  TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gty_output,
      lt_output1 TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gty_output,
      ls_output  TYPE gty_output.
DATA: o_alv    TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table,
      o_cols   TYPE REF TO cl_salv_columns,
      o_column TYPE REF TO cl_salv_column.

DATA: o_layout  TYPE REF TO cl_salv_layout,
      key       TYPE salv_s_layout_key,
      g_exit    TYPE c,
      lx_msg    TYPE REF TO cx_salv_msg,
      g_variant TYPE disvariant,
      set_lay   TYPE slis_vari.


SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b4 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-s04.
  PARAMETERS : r1 RADIOBUTTON GROUP g1 USER-COMMAND cmd DEFAULT 'X',
               r2 RADIOBUTTON GROUP g1.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b4.

SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b1 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-s01.
  SELECT-OPTIONS: so_BELNR FOR bkpf-belnr  NO INTERVALS MODIF ID Rb1.
  PARAMETERS: p_bukrs TYPE bkpf-bukrs MODIF ID rb1,
              p_gjahr TYPE bkpf-gjahr MODIF ID rb1.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b1.

SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b2 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-s02.
  PARAMETERS: p_LAUFD TYPE regup-laufd MODIF ID rb2,
              p_LAUFI TYPE regup-laufi MODIF ID rb2,
              p_XVORL TYPE regup-xvorl AS CHECKBOX MODIF ID rb2,
              p_ZBUKR TYPE regup-zbukr MODIF ID rb2.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b2.
SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b3 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-s03.
  PARAMETERS : p_file TYPE string.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b3.

.

AT SELECTION-SCREEN OUTPUT.
  LOOP AT SCREEN.
    IF screen-group1 = 'RB2' AND r1 EQ 'X'.
      screen-active = '0'.
      MODIFY SCREEN.
      CONTINUE.
    ELSEIF screen-group1 = 'RB1' AND r2 EQ 'X'.
      screen-active = '0'.
      MODIFY SCREEN.
      CONTINUE.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.

*AT SELECTION-SCREEN.


AT SELECTION-SCREEN ON VALUE-REQUEST FOR p_file.
  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>directory_browse
    CHANGING
      selected_folder      = p_file
    EXCEPTIONS
      cntl_error           = 1
      error_no_gui         = 2
      not_supported_by_gui = 3
      OTHERS               = 4.

  IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
*    f_pathname = f_path.
*    WRITE: f_pathname.
  ENDIF.

START-OF-SELECTION .

  IF r1 EQ abap_true.
    IF so_belnr IS NOT INITIAL AND p_bukrs IS NOT INITIAL AND p_gjahr IS NOT INITIAL.
    ELSE.
      MESSAGE 'Please enter all fields' TYPE 'E'.
    ENDIF.
  ELSEIF r2 EQ abap_true.
    IF p_laufd IS NOT INITIAL AND p_laufi IS NOT INITIAL AND p_zbukr IS NOT INITIAL.
    ELSE.
      MESSAGE 'Please enter all fields' TYPE 'E'.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.





  IF r1 EQ abap_true.
    SELECT bukrs, belnr, gjahr
   FROM bkpf
   WHERE
   belnr IN _belnr
   AND bukrs = @p_bukrs AND gjahr = @p_gjahr
   INTO TABLE _bkpf.


  ELSEIF r2 EQ abap_true.

    SELECT laufd,laufi,xvorl,zbukr,bukrs,belnr,gjahr
      FROM regup
      INTO TABLE (lt_regup)
      WHERE
      laufd = @p_laufd AND
      laufi = @p_laufi AND
      xvorl = @p_xvorl AND
      zbukr = @p_zbukr.
    IF sy-subrc EQ 0 .
      SELECT bukrs, belnr, gjahr
        FROM bkpf
        FOR ALL ENTRIES IN _regup
        WHERE bukrs = _regup-zbukr
        AND belnr = _regup-belnr
        AND gjahr = _regup-gjahr

        INTO TABLE _bkpf.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.
  IF lt_bkpf IS NOT INITIAL.
    SORT lt_bkpf BY belnr bukrs gjahr.
    DELETE ADJACENT DUPLICATES FROM lt_bkpf COMPARING ALL FIELDS.
    LOOP AT lt_bkpf INTO ls_bkpf.
      PERFORM download USING ls_bkpf.
    ENDLOOP.
    IF lt_output IS NOT INITIAL.
      TRY.
          cl_salv_table=>factory(
            IMPORTING
              r_salv_table = o_alv
            CHANGING
              t_table      = lt_output ).
        CATCH cx_salv_msg INTO lx_msg.
      ENDTRY.

      CALL METHOD o_alv->get_layout
        RECEIVING
          value = o_layout.

      CALL METHOD o_layout->set_key
        EXPORTING
          value = key.

entry.title: Uptime Customizing for Finance Conversion (UCFC)/CustOnTmp
entry.content:
What is CustOnTmp : The downtime-optimized conversion (doC) executes the FIN data conversion on the temporary instance during the uptime. For this, SUM needs the FIN Customizing to apply it prior to the data conversion. Until now, this required a standard conversion run prior to each doC run. In this standard run, the FIN Customizing was created and added to a transport request. Such a transport request is required to be provided to each doC run.

With the new feature Uptime Customizing for Finance Conversion, FIN delta Customizing activities can be performed directly on the temporary instance of the doC run. With this, the number of required standard conversion runs is reduced to one standard conversion at the beginning of the project. All FIN delta Customizing activities can be directly done on the temporary instance of the doC run. For each new doC iteration, the initial FIN Customizing transport request is used (created in standard conversion) together with all the delta Customizing transport requests prepared with each new iteration.  It is no longer required to always run a standard conversion before each doC cycle

Prerequisites 

  • Target release SAP S/4HANA 2022 (or higher)
  • DOC with database migration (so no in place conversion; migration is possible also for source on SAP HANA)
  • SUM 2.0 SP 23 (or higher)

Differences Between Standard doC and Uptime Customizing

The uptime customizing will by default add most application tables to the uptime handling automatically. This means, the manual selection of tables for uptime migration becomes mostly obsolete. The SUM will no longer display the respective section on downtime-optimized DMO (with file specification "table list"). If there are still tables which cause a significant runtime during phase EU_CLONE_MIG_DT_RUN they can still be added manually using CRRTABLIST.LST as in regular doC approach.

Every application table in uptime handling gets either a replication trigger or a freeze trigger in the source system.

The reasons for a freeze trigger are:

  • Customizing table with delivery class C, E or G
  • Static classification in SUM which requires a read-only restriction

Freeze Trigger 

Freeze triggers are needed to ensure the consistency of the uptime conversion. Freeze triggers are used in 3 different ways as below

  • Hard Freeze 

Freeze triggers are used to prevent customizing changes in the source system which might influence and invalidate the uptime conversion which is done in parallel to production on the temporary instance. This means that the number of freeze tables is significantly higher as in regular doC approach, although it should not add additional business restrictions as most of the freeze triggers are defined on pure customizing table which are not changed directly in a productive system. Nevertheless, the Impact analysis is of a higher importance for the doC with Uptime Customizing for Finance Conversion approach. The hard freeze will be activated during the preparation in phase SQLDB_FREEZE_TRIG_MODE_SWITCH_SMIG_TCR and will remain until the end of the doC procedure.

Please refer the   to SAP Note 2481983 - SUM Impact Analysis for downtime-optimized DMO

  • Temporary Freeze 

Some tables only be set read-only for a short period of time, for example while the Asset Accounting is prepared for the Uptime Conversion.

  • Freeze on Temporary System 

There will be freeze triggers used on the temporary instance between the SUM phases RUN_SMIG_SFIN_CUST_ON_TEMP_FREEZE and RUN_SMIG_SFIN_CUST_ON_TEMP_FREEZE_REV.

As tables must only be changed either by production operation (business users on system) on source system or by the customizing activities on the temporary system, all tables which can be changed by production operation will be set to read-only on the temporary system to avoid conflicting changes. It is, therefore, possible that a Customizing activity on the temporary instance fails with a short dump. In this case, create an incident  on component BC-UPG-DTM-TLA to clarify the access.

Some tables can be changed on source system and temporary system. Additionally, it is ensured that this does not cause a conflict or there is a special handling implementation like for number ranges. For more information, refer to section 3.1 Number Ranges in this SAP Note.

Execution 

During each doC execution, you must check in phase REQ_DOCMAX_DELTA_CUSTOMIZING that the provided FIN customizing that was added via CTI buffer is still valid.

doC with Uptime Customizing for Finance Conversion allows to add additional Customizing directly shortly before the uptime phase PARRUN_SMIG_SFIN. To do so, perform the following steps:

  1. SUM will stop in dialog phase‚ÄØREQ_DOCMAX_DELTA_CUSTOMIZING.
  2. Perform the IMG activities listed under "IMG/Conversion of Accounting to SAP S/4HANA / Preparations and Migration of Customizing" in each relevant client. Use transaction SPRO in the respective clients to perform the needed customizing steps.
    Note: to identify if there are any delta customizing activities required, the customizing activities must be executed step by step (this information can't be provided by the tool).

        Remark: The Customizing activities must be strictly restricted to the required Finance conversion Customizing.                                         3.  Start the uptime FIN conversion by continuing SUM

 Restricted tables for Uptime Handling

The following tables must not be added manually to uptime using CRRTABLIST.LST to avoid potential issues during Delta Customizing for the S/4HANA Finance Conversion.

BALHDR, BALDAT and BAL_INDX

Customizing on the Temporary Instance

  • Preparation of Number Range ‚ÄúRF_BELEG‚Äù for New Document Type for Postings in Controlling

When using the Uptime Customizing for Finance Conversion approach, the preparation of data migration requires a new document type for postings in Controlling that considers also a new number range object ‚ÄúRF_BELEG‚Äù.

Available options for Number Range Number definition for controlling document type:

  • In target system(S/4HANA):After SFIN Data Migration completion, before releasing the system to business users (the recommended one)
  • During S/4HANA Standard Customizing preparation with the inclusion into the FI customizing transport request of the CO number ranges numbers;

In source system (ECC): Before the start of S/4HANA technical activities

  • Preparations and Migration of Customizing for Controlling

Maintain Operating Concern (KEA0)‚Äù on the temporary instance is not possible due to read-only restriction on table TKES2 and CEFORMT. Execute ‚ÄúMaintain Operating Concern‚Äù only after SFIN delta migration is completed, as an after-migration activity, outside of SUM tool.

Restrictions

Depreciation calculation: Due to a read-only restriction on table T093D it is not allowed to run depreciation calculation when triggers are active in the system. This restriction only applies if table T093D is a logical pool table. If a mitigation is needed for this restriction you can get in contact with SUM development team raising an incident on BC-UPG-DTM-TLA.

 

Reference Notes:

3428570 - Executing and Monitoring Downtime-Optimized Conversion to SAP S/4HANA with Customizing on Temporary System


3388323 Executing and Monitoring Downtime-Optimized Conversion to SAP S/4HANA with SUM 2.0 SP 19

Deployment & Integration

  • Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)
    • Joule is natively embedded and updated by SAP automatically.
    • Integration with SAP FICO apps (GL, AP, AR, Asset Accounting, Controlling) is out of the box.
    • No additional installation required - users just activate and configure.
  • Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)
    • Joule can be enabled, but may require additional setup and integration.
    • Some Joule features might lag behind public cloud, because public gets innovations first.
    • Still integrates with FICO, but might require extra configuration & tenant connections to SAP BTP.

Feature Availability

  • Public Cloud
    • Joule supports all 4 interaction types (Transactional, Navigational, Informational, Analytical) directly in Fiori apps.
    • Example in FICO: ‚ÄúPost vendor invoice‚Äù ‚Üí transaction executes directly.
    • Faster delivery of Joule Agents and Joule Studio.
  • Private Cloud
    • Informational & Analytical features available early (queries, reports, insights).
    • Transactional flows may require enablement through custom skills/agents.
    • Joule Studio can still be connected via SAP BTP, but adoption speed depends on customer‚Äôs upgrade cycle.

Customization & Extensibility

  • Public Cloud
    • Limited custom coding‚Äîextensions must go through SAP BTP side-by-side development.
    • Joule skills/agents are mostly standardized.
    • Great if you want speed & standardization.
  • Private Cloud
    • More flexibility: you can create custom FICO processes, reports, and Joule agents.
    • Easier to integrate with on-prem or legacy systems.
    • Suited for companies with complex finance processes.

Data Security & Residency

  • Public Cloud
    • Data is hosted on SAP-managed hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, GCP, SAP DCs).
    • Joule queries financial data via secure APIs; customers rely on SAP‚Äôs compliance.
  • Private Cloud
    • You control hosting, location, and more of the security stack.
    • Some finance-heavy industries (banking, defense, public sector) may prefer this for regulatory reasons.

Upgrade & Innovation

  • Public Cloud
    • Quarterly upgrades ‚Üí Joule features arrive first and fastest.
    • Example: New Joule Agents for FICO tasks (like dispute resolution) appear immediately.
  • Private Cloud
    • Annual upgrades (with optional Feature Packs).
    • Joule features arrive later‚Äîinnovation follows public cloud by a few cycles.

 Which is Better for FICO?

  • Public Cloud ‚Üí Best if you want rapid innovation, standard finance processes, faster AI adoption.
  • Private Cloud ‚Üí Best if you need deep customization, strict compliance, hybrid IT integration.

 SAP Joule version requirements for S/4HANA Cloud editions (Public and Private):

  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Joule arrived as part of the Public Cloud starting around Q3 2024, and is embedded in all releases thereafter, including 2408 (August 2024) and onward.
  • While Joule is built into these releases, you still need proper entitlement and authorization to use it; this may require activation via your SAP admin or account executive.
  • There are setup guides available detailing how to activate Joule once entitlement is granted.

In Summary:

If your system is on Public Cloud release 2408 (Aug 2024) or later, Joule is already supported‚Äîassuming you've got the right access and permissions.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

  • Joule is available in the Private Cloud as well, but requires setup and configuration. It's not automatically active‚Äîyou must enable it via SAP BTP and Joule Studio.
  • Technical prerequisites include ensuring the UI5 version in your system meets or exceeds the minimum required for Joule integration. The specific UI5 version will depend on your release; you can consult SAP documentation for exact details.

In Summary:

Private Cloud systems can support Joule‚Äîbut you must set it up, ensure the UI5 stack is compatible, and configure the feature via BTP.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise (Classic)

  • Joule is not supported on on-premise S/4HANA. SAP has confirmed it's not on the current roadmap for classic on-premise systems.
  • There‚Äôs a planned strategy‚Äîpossibly coming Q1 2025‚Äîto enable Joule via SAP Build Work Zone, BTP, and Joule Studio even for on-prem systems. But as of now, Joule remains unavailable on-prem and unsupported.

Here‚Äôs how SAP Joule, SAP‚Äôs generative AI assistant, can be applied specifically within the SAP FICO (Finance & Controlling) domain:

SAP Joule Application in FICO

  • Transactional Interactions

Joule allows users to perform CRUD operations and manage financial documents via natural language‚Äîimagine asking:

  • ‚ÄúPost a vendor invoice of $5,000 to account X with due date Y.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúShow me the status of PO invoice 10234.‚Äù
    While SAP hasn't yet released out-of-the-box FICO conversational flows, Joule‚Äôs transactional model supports this kind of interaction across cloud applications.
  • Navigational Interactions

Instead of navigating through menus to reach Fiori apps like ‚ÄúDisplay GL Account Balances,‚Äù you could simply ask:

  • ‚ÄúWhere can I review G/L balances?‚Äù
    Joule will direct you to the relevant screen.
  • Informational Interactions

Straight answers instead of digging through help docs. You can ask:

  • ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the difference between cost center and profit center accounting?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúExplain account determination for automatic postings.‚Äù
    Joule will deliver concise explanations, referencing SAP documentation or your own policy documents.

Analytical Interactions

Joule bridges your natural-language queries to data analytics:

  • ‚ÄúShow me quarterly expense trends per cost center.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhich cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?‚Äù
    It returns charts, metrics, or dashboards‚Äîleveraging SAP Analytics Cloud integration.

Advanced: Joule Agents & Studio

Joule Agents

SAP has introduced AI agents‚Äîautonomous actors capable of executing complex, multi-step workflows across business functions. In FICO, custom agents could:

  • Automate dispute resolution: Collaborate across finance and service teams to validate discrepancies and propose corrections.
  • Cash collection workflows: Analyze overdue invoices, coordinate with collections, and initiate follow-ups.
    These agents are part of SAP‚Äôs cross-functional automation strategy.

Joule Studio (within SAP Build)

No-code/low-code tool to create custom skills or agents tailored for your FICO needs:

  • Build a skill to automatically generate internal financial reports, or trigger approval workflows.
  • Automate vendor reconciliation or recurring postings by designing tailored AI agents.
    These skills and agents integrate across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Key Benefits in FICO

  • Improve Insights: Conduct data reviews and root cause analysis through simple dialogue.

Real-World Usage Context -- Caveats

While SAP is rapidly developing Joule‚Äôs capabilities, many implementations remain in pilot or PoC stages. Users in forums report limited early usage, primarily for basic navigation or queries.

Here are concrete FICO scenarios where you could pilot SAP Joule and even extend it with Joule Agents / Studio:

 Pilot Scenarios in SAP FICO

  1. Invoice & Payment Handling
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúPost an invoice for vendor ABC with $12,000 due in 30 days.‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Creates the posting, validates tax code, and confirms with you.
  • Extension with Agent: Automate follow-up‚Äîif payment not cleared by due date, Joule Agent triggers a reminder email or escalates.
  1. Month-End Close Assistant
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúWhat are the pending tasks for month-end close?‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Lists open items (accruals, GR/IR clearing, reconciliations).
  • Extension with Agent: Automate recurring accrual postings and send alerts to approvers who are late in providing confirmations.
  1. Financial Analysis & Insights
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúShow me expense trend per cost center for last 6 months.‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Returns a chart (via SAC integration).
  • Extension with Agent: Forecast next quarter‚Äôs expenses and flag cost centers that may exceed budgets.
  1. Audit & Compliance Checks
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúList journal entries above $50,000 in the last quarter without approvals.‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Generates a filtered list.
  • Extension with Agent: Create an automated internal audit agent that periodically checks for compliance exceptions and notifies controllers.
  1. Treasury & Cash Management
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúWhat is today‚Äôs cash position?‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Summarizes bank balances, incoming/outgoing payments.
  • Extension with Agent: Auto-generate a daily treasury dashboard at 9 AM and send to CFO.
  1. Dispute & Collections Management
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúShow me customers with invoices overdue > 60 days.‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Lists overdue accounts.
  • Extension with Agent: An AI agent sends personalized payment reminders and schedules calls with collections staff.
  1. Budget vs. Actual Control
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúWhich cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Shows variances with drill-down.
  • Extension with Agent: Automatically notify budget owners when variances exceed a threshold (say 10%).

 How to Design in Joule Studio

In Joule Studio (within SAP Build) you can:

  1. Create a Skill ‚Üí ‚ÄúGenerate quarterly P&L by company code and send PDF to finance team.‚Äù
  2. Create an Agent ‚Üí ‚ÄúMonitor overdue vendor payments and auto-initiate dunning.‚Äù
  3. Connect Non-SAP Apps ‚Üí e.g., send approvals via MS Teams or Slack.

 

 This way, Joule moves from a copilot (answering queries) to a colleague (executing finance tasks for you).

 

Deep Dive on one of the real-world example: Vendor Invoice Posting with SAP Joule in Public vs Private Cloud.

 Example: Vendor Invoice Posting with Joule

 Scenario

A finance user wants to post a vendor invoice for Vendor 300012, amount $12,000, due in 30 days.

 Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
    ‚ÄúPost a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.
  • Joule Process:
    1. Understands the intent (‚ÄúCreate Vendor Invoice‚Äù).
    2. Pulls relevant master data (Vendor 300012 details, tax code, payment terms).
    3. Pre-fills the invoice screen in Fiori.
    4. User confirms ‚Üí Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Public Cloud:
    • Joule can immediately display the document number and due date schedule.
    • If connected to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), Joule can also show how this impacts cash outflow forecast.
    • Minimal setup ‚Üí available out-of-the-box.

    2. User manually confirms or adjusts in the classic posting screen (e.g., FB60 / MIRO).

  • Extras in Private Cloud:

    • Joule can connect to legacy non-SAP apps (like OCR invoice scanners or in-house workflow systems).

entry.title: Brazil as One of the Leading Hubs for Artificial Intelligence (2024‚Äì2025)
entry.content:
Over the past two years, Brazil has established itself as one of the main Artificial Intelligence (AI) hubs globally, standing out for its combination of public investments, expanding business ecosystem, and regulatory progress. Traditionally a leader in innovation and technology in Latin America, Brazil is now attracting international attention by accelerating the adoption of AI across strategic sectors such as finance, energy, agribusiness, and public services.

In 2024, the Brazilian government launched the Brazilian Artificial Intelligence Plan (PBIA) 2024‚Äì2028, a program with an estimated investment of R$ 23 billion dedicated to AI research, development, and infrastructure. The plan aims to strengthen technological sovereignty, foster innovation through universities, and support companies in applying AI to practical use cases, particularly in areas of public interest.

The Main pillars of the PBIA 2024‚Äì2028 are:

  • Expansion of AI research and innovation centers;
  • Tax incentives for startups and public‚Äìprivate partnerships;
  • Training and qualification of AI professionals;
  • Implementation of AI in public services (health, security, education).

This initiative positions Brazil as a regional leader in AI policy, ahead of countries like Mexico, Chile, and Argentina.

Brazil‚Äôs private sector is undergoing a phase of rapid AI adoption. By 2025, a national survey identified 396 Brazilian AI companies focused on marketing applications, reflecting diversification across generative AI, automation, analytics, and digital services.

According to a Bain & Company (2025) study, 67% of Brazilian companies now consider AI a strategic priority, a major leap from 2024, when only about 12% had active projects. This demonstrates the transition from experimental use to mature, production-level adoption.

Brazil received international investments and technological infrastructure. That's why Brazil‚Äôs consolidation as an AI hub also stems from the confidence of major global players. In September 2024, Microsoft announced a US$ 2.7 billion investment in cloud and AI infrastructure in Brazil, one of the largest technology investments in Latin American history. In 2025, Eletrobras partnered with C3 AI to modernize Brazil‚Äôs power grid using AI and machine learning, highlighting the industrial applications of advanced technologies.

These moves strengthen Brazil‚Äôs position as a regional hub for data and high-performance computing, essential for scaling generative AI and automation initiatives.

Despite major progress, Brazil still faces structural challenges. A SAP Brazil (March 2025) survey revealed that:

  • 29% of companies lack clarity on how to integrate AI into their business systems;
  • 28% cite a shortage of skilled professionals as the main obstacle.

On the regulatory front, Brazil has emerged as a key player. In 2024, the National Data Protection Authority (ANPD) suspended Meta Platforms‚Äô privacy policy, which used Brazilians‚Äô personal data to train generative AI models. This decision marked an important milestone in ethical governance and digital sovereignty, aligning Brazil with European-style data protection principles.

The main sectors driving AI growth in Brazil include:

  • Finance and digital payments: automation and predictive analytics;
  • Energy: smart grids and real-time system optimization;
  • Agribusiness: crop forecasting and climate analytics;
  • Healthcare: assisted diagnostics and telemedicine;
  • Public administration: chatbots and natural language processing for citizen services.

These industries attract investments from both large corporations and local startups, making Brazil a fertile ground for experimentation and innovation.

About the Outlook for 2025 and Beyond the trends indicate continued expansion of generative AI and process automation in Brazilian companies. By the end of 2025, it is expected that:

  • Over 60% of corporate AI solutions in Brazil will involve generative models;
  • The country will consolidate international research and training partnerships;
  • The General Artificial Intelligence Law (under discussion in Congress) will advance the national governance framework.

With growing public and private investments, Brazil is on track to become a Latin American reference in AI innovation and ethics, combining economic growth with responsible technological governance.

The 2024‚Äì2025 period marks a strategic turning point for AI in Brazil, shifting from an emerging topic to a core pillar of industrial and business competitiveness. The alignment between government vision, international investments, and technological maturity positions Brazil as one of the leading AI hubs in the Southern Hemisphere, with the potential to export technology, talent, and regulatory best practices.

Our Cash Flow Intelligence App leverages data from Supply Chain, Sales, Treasury, Accounts Receivable, Accounts Payable, and real-time Bank Balances to deliver accurate forecasting and scenario simulation, ensuring that financial teams have a clear, data-driven view of their company‚Äôs liquidity at any time.

In France we have a legal requirement to submit a file of accounting entries for the closed fiscal year in a dematerialized format (Article L47 A I ) which is effective from 01.01.2014.

Upon receiving request from the tax authorities, a company has 15 days to prepare and submit the FEC file. In case of failing to deliver the FEC file or in the event of non-compliance, companies could face significant penalties

This file consists of entries after inventory operations, excluding centralization entries and excluding entries for balancing expense and revenue accounts. It includes the entries for the recovery of balances from the previous fiscal year and contains, for each entry, all accounting data present in the company's computerized accounting system, with the first eighteen pieces of information required to correspond, in order, to those listed in the following table:

 

 

Further information about the legal requirements can be found here

Article L47 A - Book of Tax Procedures ‚Äì L√©gifrance

Article A47 A-1 - Livre des proc√©dures fiscales - L√©gifrance

How to generate the FEC file from SAP? 

DRC or DART

Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC)

It enables you to create, process, and monitor electronic documents and statutory reports. As a result, your company stays compliant with local legal obligations.

Statutory reporting has been localized for use by businesses with operations in the country/region and it comprises functions designed for laws and business practices relevant in the country/region.

You can generate the audit file for France using the Run Statutory Reports app. This file is referred to as "FEC - Fichier des √âcritures Comptables".

Further information can be found here

Supported Compliance Tasks by Country/Region | SAP Help Portal

Audit File (FEC) | SAP Help Portal

Data Retention Tool (DART)

The Data Retention Tool (DART) helps SAP users to meet the legal requirements concerning data retention and data transfer for tax auditing. You can use DART to extract and store data that is relevant to tax from SAP applications at regular intervals. DART extracts the data into sequential files and provides tools that you can use to display and evaluate the stored data.

In general, two steps are required in DART to create machine-readable files for the tax auditor.

The first step in DART involves generating extract files that capture data based on the selected company code and areas like FI, CO, SD, and MM, with customizable restrictions.

In the second step, extract files are transformed into view files according to tax auditor specifications by defining which segments are included and how they are combined.

Further information can be found here

Introduction to the Data Retention Tool (DART) | SAP Help Portal

What are the technical prerequisites for FEC solution by DART?

The recommendation from SAP is to be on the highest version of DART with all the latest notes implemented.

you can check the DART version in the SE11.

You should choose there the "TYPE GROUP": DART1. Then click display

 

The most important technical prerequisites are included in this note

2162977 - DART: Order of implementation of notes for FEC - SAP for Me

Depending on release & support package of the relevant system, some of them should have been delivered by default.

Configuration for DART can be checked in SAP Help Portal

Configuration | SAP Help Portal

DART is often pre-configured for FEC by the installed SAP notes. You mainly need to Configure the Extract File Directories and set directory paths

What is the exact business process?

The prerequisite before running these processes is that your fiscal year is completely closed!

1st step Posting of opening balances France

2nd step Create DART extracts

3rd step Generation of the FEC

Posting of opening balances France

Run Program RFOPENPOSTING_FR with Tcode SE38 or Tcode FAGL_FR_03

This report creates opening entries for balance sheet accounts from the previous year in accordance with the French requirement to submit posting data to the French tax authorities.

Based on the account balances and open items on the key date, FI documents are posted and form the basis of the data extract. These postings represent the balance carryforward but do not generate balances.

For these postings, no subledger documents (customer/vendor/Asset Accounting) are written.

No open items are generated.

The report is available for classic General Ledger Accounting and new General Ledger Accounting.

The documents are specially indicated:

1) The document status is 'O' (balance sheet opening entry).

2) The reference transaction is 'GLYEC' (year-end closing document).

3) The documents are posted in period '0' of the carryforward year.

Documents are generated for each account, customer, and vendor. Information about the customer and vendor is stored in the LIFNR/KUNNR fields as well as in the assignment.

The balances of the respective balance sheet accounts are cleared against "Balance Sheet Account - Opening" on the selection screen.

The posted documents can be reversed with the FI reversal transactions (FB08/F.80).

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Customer Payments ‚Äì Transition and Future with APIs
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Customer Payments - Transition and Future with APIs

SAP has transitioned SAP Cloud for Customer Payments into maintenance mode and removed it from the price list (as of September 2, 2024). The solution will continue to be supported for existing customers under active contracts, but no further development or investments are made. Customers are encouraged to transition to the new API-based approach in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and On-Premise/Private Cloud.

Accounts receivable processes today are often costly, manual, and time-consuming. Many businesses face delays in cash collection, lack of transparency for their customers, and high operational costs for invoice and payment handling.

With the new S/4HANA APIs, SAP enables customers and partners to build modern customer-facing portals that accelerate the invoice-to-cash process and support automated cash collection. These portals empower end customers with self-service capabilities, reducing manual workload while improving the customer experience.

Capabilities Enabled by S/4HANA APIs

Using the APIs already available in S/4HANA On-Premise, Private Cloud, and Public Cloud businesses can:

APIs for Electronic Bill Presentment and Payment

  • Pay & manage bills: Select open items, create payments (via direct debit or credit card when SAP Digital Payments Add-on is integrated), view or cancel payments in process
  • Display account statements: View and download all items for a specific time period for the customer invoice, credit memo, and / or incoming payment(s)

Other APIs

  • Match payments with invoices: Improve reconciliation through payment matching
  • Create and manage payment advice: Issue or cancel payment advice efficiently
  • Make ad-hoc payments: Support payments on account or down payment requests
  • Manage account master data: View and update account and master data directly

These capabilities can be embedded into custom-built portals or integrated into existing customer-facing portals, offering flexibility for each company‚Äôs unique landscape.

This new API approach is not a one-to-one successor, but provides greater flexibility:

  • APIs are released for S/4HANA On-Premise, Private Cloud, and Public Cloud (from release 2508.02)
  • Customers can build their own portals, integrate into existing ones, or leverage partner-built portals
  • Partners are actively working with SAP to deliver ready-to-use solutions based on these APIs

Partner Solutions: Ready-to-Use Customer Payment Portals

To help customers accelerate adoption, SAP partners already offer pre-built customer payment and self-service portals leveraging the new APIs.

Kumulon ‚Äì KUMOsphere B2B Payment Portal

Kumulon delivers a cloud-native, template-based portal built on SAP BTP with full support for SAP‚Äôs latest payment APIs.

  • Real cloud services, no legacy code ‚Äì innovative SAP Cloud technologies only
  • Flexible templates ‚Äì adapt quickly to customer needs while jumpstarting projects
  • Secure integration ‚Äì SAP Cloud Connector ensures safe on-premise-to-cloud connectivity
  • Flexible deployment ‚Äì operate in your own BTP environment or as SaaS on Kumulon‚Äôs BTP

üîó KUMOsphere ‚Äì B2B Payment Portal on SAP Store

Acuiti Labs ‚Äì Customer Self Care and Payment Portal

Acuiti Labs offers a SaaS-based self-service and payment portal for S/4HANA Private and Public Cloud (Sales Billing/FI-AR) leveraging the S/4HANA APIs.

  • Customer self-service portal ‚Äì empowers end customers to manage invoices and payments directly
  • Cross-solution experience ‚Äì already proven in BRIM (FI-CA), Subscription Billing, and Q2C portals
  • Accelerated go-live ‚Äì prebuilt solution reduces implementation effort

üîó Acuiti Labs Customer Portal on SAP Store

Learn More

APIs for Electronic Billing and Presentment ‚Äì S/4HANA On-Premise (OP), Private Cloud

  • All APIs part of the Electronic Billing and Presentment scope are shipped via SAP Note 3505741
  • For other required APIs outside the package, please see also the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for more details, for example: Managing Payment Advice is available, see Payment Advice (A2X).
  • For more information, visit the SAP Help Portal.

APIs for EBPP Payment Request ‚Äì S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • Please see the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for the available EBPP Payment Request APIs.
  • For other required APIs outside the package, please see also the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for more details, for example:
    • Match payments with invoices & Create and manage payment advice, Payment Advice.
    • Make ad-hoc payments, Journal Entry -Post
    • Manage account master data, Business Partner
    • Customer account balance, Accounting Document - Read
  • For more information, visit the SAP Help Portal.

Summary

SAP Cloud for Customer Payments is moving into maintenance mode, and the future lies in API-driven, flexible customer payment portals. Customers can now:

  • Plan their transition to S/4HANA API-based solutions
  • Either build their own portals or leverage ready-to-use partner solutions from the SAP Store

This shift gives businesses greater flexibility, faster innovation, and improved customer experiences in the accounts receivable process.

entry.title: Unify your close: task orchestration with SAP Advanced Financial Closing and SAP Central Finance
entry.content:
Step-by-step guide to cross-system orchestration

Dear finance experts,

In a Central Finance scenario, managing a month-end close across both source ERP and Central Finance systems presents a unique challenge: how do you maintain a single, seamless process and retain transparency over the overall status of your financial close? SAP Advanced Financial Closing (AFC) is the answer. 

This guide provides a clear path to managing your financial close across systems. We'll demonstrate how to configure AFC to manage a unified task list, create dependencies between source and central tasks, and gain complete cross-system visibility through AFC‚Äôs embedded reporting capabilities. 

We‚Äôll be looking at an example where Central Payment is activated for a company code that is managed in AFC. In this case, some closing activities of the AP/AR payment and clearing processes are executed in the Central Finance system, while other activities are still executed in the source system. 

While we‚Äôre looking at an example with a single source system here, the same is possible in a landscape with multiple source systems.

Enable Central-Finance-specific reports and apps with‚ÄØSAP Advanced Financial Closing 

Prerequisite: Specify communication systems for both source and CFIN system 

During the entity close in‚ÄØSAP Advanced Financial Closing, you‚Äôll need to add Central-Finance-specific activities like Central Finance comparison reports, manage temporary postings, and so on. To make these tasks available in SAP Advanced Financial Closing, you first need to create task models in the communication system‚Äôs local settings. The local settings allow you to define which parameters shall be derived from the task list context while you can specify others directly as part of the program registration of the task model.  

In our example, we'll create two CFIN-specific tasks: 

  • Job task to run the Balance Comparison Report (steps 1 ‚Äì 5)
  • Fiori app for Manage Temporary Postings (steps 4 ‚Äì 5) 

Documentation reference: 

ABAP Programs in SAP Advanced Financial Closing 
SAP Fiori Applications in SAP Advanced Financial Closing 

  1. Register an ABAP program for parameter mapping 

    As a first step, you need to register an ABAP program for parameter mapping. This enables you to define parameters and parameter values afterwards, and create a task model for this program. 

  2. Maintain parameters for the ABAP program you've already registered 

    By assigning the FYEAR and FYEPE parameter types to the respective parameters, we ensure that the fiscal year and posting period are derived automatically from the context of the task list in which the task will be used.

    For CFIN-specific tasks, however, parameters like Company Code or G/L Account often refer to source system values. To ensure the correct source value is used, we do not set these parameters to be derived from the task list context, hence no parameter type is assigned here. 

  3. Define fixed values or value ranges for specific parameters 

    Next, we define some parameter values for the balance comparison report directly in the task model, so they will be applied wherever the task model is used. Here, we define the values for the currency type and logical system. 


  4. Define closing business transaction types 

    Now, we define the closing business transaction type (called task model type in AFC) and define the balance comparison report as a job and manage temporary postings as Fiori application. The closing business transaction type represents the semantic task that can be used in combination with different variants.

  5. Define task model 

    Finally, the task model that will be used in AFC is defined as the combination of our previously created closing business transaction type and variant ID. 

  6. Trigger synchronization in SAP Advanced Financial Closing 

Documentation reference: Synchronization of Communication Systems 

After you‚Äôre finished creating the task models, go to SAP Advanced Financial Closing and start the synchronization with the respective communication system from the Monitor Communication Systems app. 

 

Lay the foundation for reporting: group company codes 

Before building the process in our closing task list, we need to teach Advanced Financial Closing to see the distributed company codes as a single entity for seamless reporting. 

Company codes from the source system and company codes from the Central Finance system, even if named identically, are recognized in SAP Advanced Financial Closing as separate objects. Company codes that are semantically the same may also slightly differ in their naming. 

For this purpose, we‚Äôll make use of company code groups. These groups allow bundling of company codes according to four different characteristics.

Documentation reference: How to Manage Company Code Groups 

  1. From the SAP Advanced Financial Closing launchpad, open the app Manage Company Code Groups. If the app is not visible, verify that you have the required access rights. 
  2. Decide on one of the grouping characteristics to be used for the mapping of company codes between the source system and the Central Finance system.
  3. For each logical company code, create a company code group and assign the source system company code and the equivalent company code from the Central Finance system. 

Each company code is now represented as a group and can be applied in the embedded reporting. In our example, we map the company code CFP1.

Build the process: create closing structure 

Next, we‚Äôll set up the closing structure for tasks running centrally as well as in the source. 

Our goal in this example is to demonstrate how we can represent central payment closing tasks in one seamless sequence together with the tasks that run in the source system. 

Documentation reference: How to Create Task List Templates 

  1. Open the app Manage Closing Task Lists and create a new task list template. 
  2. Firstly, add both systems to the same task list template in the closing structure. This will later allow us to run tasks in a sequence even if they run in different communication systems. 
  3. Create the central payment tasks as well as other required tasks based on task models from the Central Finance system.
  4. Create tasks running in the source system. 

The folder structure in the following screenshot shows an example containing multiple process areas. The accounts receivable tasks and accounts payable tasks run in Central Finance but depend on tasks in fixed assets, which are located in the source system.

Additionally, we need to add the two Central-Finance-specific tasks which we have already created as task models in the connected Central Finance system. 

Documentation reference: How to Create Tasks 

  1. Create a separate folder for Central Finance tasks. 
  2. Edit the folder and choose ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù, then ‚ÄúCreate Task from Model‚Äù 
  3. Search for the two tasks created previously: ‚ÄúManage Temporary Postings‚Äù and ‚ÄúBalance Comparison Report‚Äù. 
  4. Create the tasks, assign users responsible and processing users, and save the folder. 

Now we have all the tasks that we need inside our closing structure. Our next step is to define the dependencies between the tasks. Specifically, ‚ÄúManage Temporary Postings‚Äù shall be processed after the depreciation posting run in the source system is completed, followed by an automatic execution of the balance comparison report.

Documentation reference: How to Maintain Task Dependencies 

  1. Open the Manage Temporary Postings task. 
  2. Go to the tab ‚ÄúDependencies‚Äù. 
  3. Inside the dependencies tab, choose ‚ÄúEdit Dependencies‚Äù. 
  4. Maintain the Depreciation Posting run as a predecessor. 
  5. Maintain the Balance Comparison Report as a successor. 

The screenshot below shows how we added the required predecessor and successor tasks to ‚ÄúManage Temporary Postings‚Äù. In the same way, after the balance is confirmed to have no remaining differences, the accounts receivable and accounts payable can be closed, so these two tasks are maintained as successors.

Note:
When adding custom task models, consider the behavior of the reports. For example, the balance comparison report will return a success status when it‚Äôs finished, independent of whether differences exist or not. For this reason, we‚Äôve defined the report to require an approval before subsequent tasks can be started. 

Our resulting task sequence looks as depicted in the screenshot below.

  

Ready for processing: generate task list 

Let‚Äôs assume that all relevant task information, user assignments, and parameters have been maintained for our task list template. Then, we can generate the task list for a specific period and test how our central finance tasks are processed and represented in the embedded reporting. 

Documentation reference: How to Generate and Release Task Lists 

  1. Open the task list template. 
  2. On the template‚Äôs header, choose ‚ÄúGenerate Task List‚Äù. 
  3. Provide the closing key date, fiscal year, and period. 
  4. Choose ‚ÄúRelease Task List‚Äù. 

Let‚Äôs have a look at the resulting task list. 

  1. Navigate to the ‚ÄúTask Lists‚Äù tab. Remove filters if required. 
  2. Find the task list you‚Äôve generated. 
  3. On the tasks tab, find the Balance Comparison Report and open it.  

Here, we can have a look at the task‚Äôs parameters. We see the parameters that we‚Äôve maintained in the task model. Additionally, the fiscal year and posting period have been derived from the task list context when the task list was generated.

Run the task chain: process closing tasks 

Since we‚Äôve already released the task list, we can also view it in the Process Closing Tasks app, and follow the processing of tasks on the dependency chain for the source system and the Central Finance system in one view. 

Documentation reference: Process Closing Tasks 

  1. Open the Process Closing Tasks app. 
  2. Navigate to the task list.
  3. Switch the view option on the right side of the screen to view the tasks either in a list, in the context of the closing structure, or in the dependencies view. 

In our example, the central payment tasks are completed, and the period closure tasks can be performed once the balance comparison report has been run and approved.

Follow the progress: report by logical company code

Lastly, we want to follow the progress of the overall close. Based on our company code mapping for CFP1, we can use the ‚ÄúCompany Code Grouping Characteristic 1‚Äù to report on all CFP1 tasks, independent of whether they run in the source system or the Central Finance system. 

Documentation reference: Reporting 

  1. Open the app ‚ÄúFinancial Close Overview ‚Äì Organizational Unit View‚Äù. 
  2. Filter for your generated task list. 
  3. Familiarize yourself with the available cards.
  4. View the card ‚ÄúCompany Code Grouping Characteristic 1‚Äù for KPIs by company codes according to our previous mapping. 

In our small example, we only have this one company code but we see that the task completion of CFP1 is at 55 % and 18 tasks are overdue.

When clicking on the company code group CFP1, we navigate to the Closing Task Completion app with the filter for the company code group already applied, and we can dive deeper into the task statuses.

Conclusion

By following the steps outlined in this guide, you have successfully configured SAP Advanced Financial Closing to manage a unified closing process across both your source and Central Finance systems. Through the creation of custom task models, the strategic use of company code groups, and the definition of cross-system dependencies, you can build a seamless task sequence for a complex landscape. This approach not only automates activities but also provides cross-system visibility through embedded reporting, empowering your finance team to execute a faster and more transparent month-end close.
